manuscripts.title: Optimal Contract, Delegated Investment, and Information Acquisition
manuscripts.status_details: 2 active selections; 2 invited; 2 agreed; 1 declined; 0 returned
manuscripts.abstract: Abstract: This paper examines a model of delegated investment within a noisy rational expectations equilibrium framework. Portfolio managers can acquire costly signals about asset payoffs but incur portfolio management costs. They are compensated by delegating investors and make investment decisions on their behalf. The optimal contract features a benchmark component that helps mitigate agency frictions arising from these management costs. The precision of the private signals chosen by managers is determined endogenously through market equilibrium. Private and public signals act as substitutes. When portfolio management costs increase, both the performance and benchmark components of the optimal contract rise, however fewer private signals are incorporated into the public signal, reducing the informational efficiency of prices. When a social planner places sufficient weight on the welfare of direct investors or liquidity providers, the socially optimal equilibrium yields greater price informational efficiency compared to the decentralized equilibrium.
manuscripts.funding_information: There are no funders to report for this submission
manuscripts.data_availability_statement: Data sharing not applicable to this article as no datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.

Invitation to Review for Mathematical Finance
communication_timeline.snippet: 07-Aug-2025 Dear Pr. Durandard: Manuscript ID MAFI-2025-0212 entitled "Optimal Contract, Delegated Investment, and Information Acquisition" with Professor Xing as contact author has been
communication_timeline.body:
07-Aug-2025

Dear Pr. Durandard:

Manuscript ID MAFI-2025-0212 entitled "Optimal Contract, Delegated Investment, and Information Acquisition" with Professor Xing as contact author has been submitted to Mathematical Finance.

I invite you to review this manuscript.  The abstract appears at the end of this letter, along with the names of the authors.  Please let me know as soon as possible if you will be able to accept my invitation to review.  If you are unable to review at this time, I would appreciate you recommending another expert reviewer.  You may e-mail me with your reply or click the appropriate link at the bottom of the page to automatically register your reply with our online manuscript submission and review system.

Authors of good quality manuscripts that we are unable to accept may be referred to journals published by Wiley within a similar subject area. If authors choose to pursue this option, their manuscript (along with the peer reviewer reports, if any) will be transferred to the receiving journal to expedite any further evaluation and the editor's decision. The primary objective of this collaboration is to reduce the incidence of redundant reviews, thus lessening the burden on the already overstretched community of peer reviewers. By accepting this invitation to review for this journal, you also consent to the possible transfer of your name, email, and review to a relevant alternate journal. 

Once you accept my invitation to review this manuscript, you will be notified via e-mail about how to access ScholarOne, our online manuscript submission and review system.  You will then have access to the manuscript and reviewer instructions in your Reviewer Center.

I realize that our expert reviewers greatly contribute to the high standards of the Journal, and I thank you for your present and/or future participation.

Sincerely,

Professor Dylan Possamai
Associate Editor, Mathematical Finance
dylan.possamai@math.ethz.ch

Mathematical Finance

*** PLEASE NOTE: This is a two-step process. After clicking on the link, you will be directed to a webpage to confirm. *** 

Agreed: https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/mafi?URL_MASK=19922eb02bf04c3dace860176a020148

Declined: https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/mafi?URL_MASK=953b9bad85444e3ca3e0664993ee4ae0

Unavailable: https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/mafi?URL_MASK=989eacb9cc704e14a7b04865dfa1d1ce


MANUSCRIPT DETAILS

TITLE: Optimal Contract, Delegated Investment, and Information Acquisition

AUTHORS: Xing, Hao; Zhang, Yuyang

ABSTRACT: This paper examines a model of delegated investment within a noisy rational expectations equilibrium framework. Portfolio managers can acquire costly signals about asset payoffs but incur portfolio management costs. They are compensated by delegating investors and make investment decisions on their behalf. The optimal contract features a benchmark component that helps mitigate agency frictions arising from these management costs. The precision of the private signals chosen by managers is determined endogenously through market equilibrium. Private and public signals act as substitutes. When portfolio management costs increase, both the performance and benchmark components of the optimal contract rise, however fewer private signals are incorporated into the public signal, reducing the informational efficiency of prices. When a social planner places sufficient weight on the welfare of direct investors or liquidity providers, the socially optimal equilibrium yields greater price informational efficiency compared to the decentralized equilibrium.

By submitting a manuscript to or reviewing for this publication, your name, email address, and affiliation, and other contact details the publication might require, will be used for the regular operations of the publication, including sharing with the publisher (Wiley) and partners for production, publication and improvements to the authoring process. The publication and the publisher recognize the importance of protecting the personal information collected from users in the operation of these services, and have practices in place to ensure that steps are taken to maintain the security, integrity, and privacy of the personal data collected and processed. You can learn more at www.wiley.com/privacy. In case you don’t want to be contacted by this publication again, please send an email to mathfinance@wiley.com.

I would like to help but I am swamped with my own editorial duties (I am 
the main theory editor at the JPE and it taking a lot of time).

Alternative reviewers would include:

Théo Durandard (UIUC) theod@illinois.edu
Aaron Kolb (Indiana) kolba@iu.edu
Chiara Margaria (BU) margaria@bu.edu

Amitiés,
Bruno

manuscripts.title: Optimal investment and consumption under forward utilities with relative performance concerns
manuscripts.status_details: 2 active selections; 2 invited; 2 agreed; 2 declined; 1 returned
manuscripts.abstract: Abstract: We study a n-player and mean-field portfolio optimization problem under relative performance concerns with non-zero volatility, for wealth and consumption. The consistency assumption defining forward relative performance criteria leads to a sufficient characterization of such preferences with mean of a HJB-SPDE which highlights the link between wealth and consumption utility, and also characterizes the optimal strategies. In particular, forward relative performance criteria with a wealth utility of CRRA type and separable time and space dependence necessarily have a consumption utility of the same form, with the same risk aversion parameter. This characterization gives a better understanding of the drift condition ensuring time consistency. In this setting, we establish closed form of the Nash equilibrium for both the n-player and mean field problems. We also provide some numerical examples.

manuscripts.title: Competitive optimal portfolio selection in a non-Markovian financial market: A backward stochastic differential equation study
manuscripts.status_details: 2 active selections; 2 invited; 2 agreed; 0 declined; 0 returned
manuscripts.abstract: Abstract: This paper studies a competitive optimal portfolio selection problem in a model where the interest rate, the appreciation rate and volatility rate of the risky asset are all stochastic processes, thus forming a non-Markovian financial market. In our model, all investors (or agents) aim to obtain an above-average wealth at the end of the common investment horizon. This competitive optimal portfolio problem is indeed a non-zero sum stochastic differential game problem. The quadratic BSDE theory is applied to tackle the problem and Nash equilibria in suitable spaces are found. We discuss both the CARA and CRRA utility cases. For the CARA utility case, there are three possible scenarios depending on market and competition parameters: a unique Nash equilibrium, no Nash equilibrium, and infinite Nash equilibria. The Nash equilibrium is given by the solutions of a quadratic BSDE and a linear BSDE with unbounded coefficient when it is unique. Different from the wealth-independent Nash equilibria in the existing literature, the equilibrium in our paper is of feedback form of wealth. For the CRRA utility case, the issue is a bit more complicated than the CARA utility case. We prove the solvability of a new kind of quadratic BSDEs with unbounded coefficients. A decoupling technology is used to relate the Nash equilibrium to a series of 1-dimensional quadratic BSDEs. With the help of this decoupling technology, we can even give the limiting strategies for both cases when the number of agents tends to be infinite.

communication_timeline.snippet: 30-Aug-2025 Dear Professor Hamadene: Recently, you agreed to review Manuscript ID MAFI-2024-0167, entitled "Competitive optimal portfolio selection in a non-Markovian financial market: A backward
communication_timeline.body:
30-Aug-2025

Dear Professor Hamadene:

Recently, you agreed to review Manuscript ID MAFI-2024-0167, entitled "Competitive optimal portfolio selection in a non-Markovian financial market: A backward stochastic differential equation study."  A previous e-mail was sent to you four weeks ago as a reminder that your review was due.  I have yet to receive your review of this manuscript.

We recognise that the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic may affect your ability to return your review to us within the requested timeframe. If this is the case, please let us know.

Please complete and then submit your review via ScholarOne - https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/mafi.

Do not hesitate to contact me if I can be of any assistance.

Sincerely,
Professor Dylan Possamai
Associate Editor, Mathematical Finance
dylan.possamai@math.ethz.ch

communication_timeline.body:
30-Apr-2025

Dear Professor Possamai:

Manuscript ID MAFI-2024-0167 entitled "Competitive optimal portfolio selection in a non-Markovian financial market: A backward stochastic differential equation study" with Panpan Zhang as contact author has been assigned to you and is now available in your Associate Editor Center at https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/mafi.

Please select reviewers for this manuscript by 03-May-2025.  If, for any reason, you are unable to serve as Associate Editor for this manuscript, please notify me immediately so that I can reassign it.


Sincerely,
Rama Cont
Editor, Mathematical Finance
